org.tantalum

Class Task

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.tantalum.Task
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AsyncTask, HttpGetter, StaticCache.GetLocalTask, StaticWebCache.GetAnywhereTask, StaticWebCache.GetWebTask

    public abstract class Task
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Runnable
    A Task is the base unit of work in Tantalum. It is a single unit of work executed on a background worker thread pool. The thread pool pulls Tasks from a common queue. Each Task is fork()ed and executed only one time after which it is discarded or passed as a value object. Tasks receive an input value. During execution this value is mutated into an output value which is from that point immutable. Each Task is a functional programming "function" for asynchronous concurrent fulfillment on a background thread pool. In other functional programming platforms the function filled by Task is known as a "future" (C++ 11 stdlib) or a "promise" (JavaScript frameworks such as RX). All asynchronous Tasks can be converted for synchronous usage by calling get() which will block until execution completes. Any piece of code which runs in response to an event and does not explicitly need to be run on the user interface (UI) thread is usually implemented in an extension of Task.exec(). It will automatically be executed on a background worker thread once fork() has been called. A Task which has Task.UI will, after successful completion on a background worker thread, be forked to the platform's UI Thread after successful completion. The UI Thread will then call their run() method for synchronous, serialized interface updates. A Task is often an anonymous inner class extending Task and adding a lambda expression (bit of asynchronously executable code). Such inner classes are closures and exhibit lambda capture (convenient reference access to final values in the outer scope). Since inner classes maintain an object reference to their parent instance, the outer scope parent can not be garbage collected until the Task completes. In cases where rapid heap memory release is critical and the outer scope is holding large objects that should be freed before the Task executes or completes, a named static inner class may be more suitable. Long running Tasks may periodically check their status to see if cancel(false, "reason") has been signaled. They can be stopped instantly by calling cancel(true, "reason"). Task.exec() code which may be canceled should utilize try {..}finally{..} to clean any associated resources.

      Override the default shutdown behavior If for example you want an ongoing task to finish if it has already started when the shutdown signal comes, but be removed from the queue if it has not yet started, set to Task.DEQUEUE_ON_SHUTDOWN Note that items passed to Worker.queueShutdownTask() ignore this value and will all run normally to completion during shutdown unless the platform (not the application) initiated the shutdown and slow shutdown Tasks result in a shutdown times-out.

    • Field Detail

      • UI

        public static final int UI
        The task is queued at HIGH_PRIORITY to be the next task started as with HIGH_PRIORITY. You may alternately binary "or" this value with any other state. For example, myTask.fork(Task.SERIAL | Task.UI) After the Task completes successfully and enters the FINISHED state, Task.run() will be forked to the UI thread. All Tasks at this priority must therefore override run(), and most will want the to use the result available with Task.getValue().
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • HIGH_PRIORITY

        public static final int HIGH_PRIORITY
        Start the task as soon as possible. The fork() operation will place this as the next Task to be completed unless subsequent HIGH_PRIORITY fork operations occur before a Worker start execution. This is the normal priority for user interface tasks where the user expects a fast response regardless of previous incomplete requests they may have made.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • NORMAL_PRIORITY

        public static final int NORMAL_PRIORITY
        Start execution after any previously fork()ed work, first in is usually first out, however multiple Workers in parallel means that execution start and completion order is not guaranteed.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • LOW_PRIORITY

        public static final int LOW_PRIORITY
        Start execution if there is nothing else for the Workers to do. At least one Worker will always be left idle for immediate activation if only LOW_PRIORITY work is queued for execution. This is intended for background tasks such as pre-fetch and pre-processing of data that doe not affect the current user view.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • SERIAL

        public static final int SERIAL
        All SERIAL tasks are executed on a single thread for guaranteed sequential execution in the order in which they are fork()ed. This is normally used for persistence operations like flash write. In the case of cached content it is not necessary to read in serial order since the heap memory cache will shield out-of-order read inconsistencies which would otherwise occur. Note that in some cases it is preferable for you to sequence items explicitly within a single Task or by the sequence with which one Task chains to or forks other Tasks.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • SHUTDOWN

        public static final int SHUTDOWN
        Start execution when PlatformUtils.getInstance().shutdown() is called, and do not exit the program until all such shutdown tasks are completed. Note that if shutdown takes too long and the phone is telling the application to exit, then the phone may give the application a limited time window (typically around 3 seconds) to complete all shutdown activities before killing the application. Shutdown time can be unlimited if the application initiates the exit as by clicking an "Exit" button in the application, but since this can never be guaranteed to be the only shutdown sequence, you must design for quick shutdown.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • LARGE_MEMORY_MUTEX

        public static final java.lang.Object LARGE_MEMORY_MUTEX
        While holding no other locks, synchronize on the following during critical code sections if your processing routine will temporarily need a large amount of memory. Only one such activity can be active at a time.

      • MAX_TIMEOUT

        public static final int MAX_TIMEOUT
        For join(), if a timeout is not specified, no thread can wait more than 2 minutes.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • PENDING

        public static final int PENDING
        status: created and forked for execution by a background Worker thread, but no Worker has yet been free to accept this queued Task
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • FINISHED

        public static final int FINISHED
        status: exec() has finished. If this is a UI thread there still may be pending activity for the user interface thread
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

        state: cancel() was called
        See Also:

      • EXECUTE_NORMALLY_ON_SHUTDOWN

        public static final int EXECUTE_NORMALLY_ON_SHUTDOWN
        Task will run without interruption or dequeue during shutdown
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DEQUEUE_ON_SHUTDOWN

        public static final int DEQUEUE_ON_SHUTDOWN
        Tasks which have not yet started are removed from the task queue when an application shutdown begins.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DEQUEUE_BUT_LEAVE_RUNNING_IF_ALREADY_STARTED_ON_SHUTDOWN

        public static final int DEQUEUE_BUT_LEAVE_RUNNING_IF_ALREADY_STARTED_ON_SHUTDOWN
        If a Task is still queued but not yet started, you can request notification of the shutdown in order to complete some cleanup activity. Note that you should usually not be holding resources when queued, so cleanup of that form is probably a design error. You may however want to briefly notify the user. An alternative to this is to create a Task that is run at shutdown time using Worker.queueShutdownTask(Task).
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DEQUEUE_OR_CANCEL_ON_SHUTDOWN

        public static final int DEQUEUE_OR_CANCEL_ON_SHUTDOWN
        Default shutdown behavior. If you explicitly do not want your Task to be cancel(true)ed during shutdown or silently cancel(false)ed when it is queued, use this shutdown behavior. This is useful for example if you need to complete an ongoing Flash memory write operation. An alternative to this is to create a Task that is run at shutdown time using Worker.queueShutdownTask(Task).
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • status

        protected int status
        The current execution state, one of several predefined constants

      • Task

        public Task(java.lang.Object initialValue)
        Create a Task with the specified input value. The default action is for the output value to be the same as the input value, however many Tasks will return their own value.
        Parameters:
        initialValue -

    • Method Detail

      • getShutdownBehaviour

        public final int getShutdownBehaviour()
        Return the currently set shutdown behavior
        Returns:

      • setShutdownBehaviour

        public final Task setShutdownBehaviour(int shutdownBehaviour)
        Override the default shutdown behavior If for example you want an ongoing task to finish if it has already started when the shutdown signal comes, but be removed from the queue if it has not yet started, set to Task.DEQUEUE_ON_SHUTDOWN Note that items passed to Worker.queueShutdownTask() ignore this value and will all run normally to completion during shutdown unless the platform (not the application) initiated the shutdown and slow shutdown Tasks result in a shutdown times-out. If this occurs during persistent state write operations, behavior is unpredictable, so it is best to write state as-you-go so that you can shut down quickly.
        Parameters:
        shutdownBehaviour -
        Returns:

      • getValue

        protected final java.lang.Object getValue()
        Get the current value of this Task. Access is synchronized and execution is not forced execution. If the task has not yet been executed, this will return the input value. If the task has been executed, this will be the return value.
        Returns:

      • get

        public final java.lang.Object get()
                           throws java.lang.InterruptedException,
                                  CancellationException,
                                  TimeoutException
        Execute synchronously if needed and return the resulting value. This is similar to join() with a very long timeout. Note that a MAX_TIMEOUT of 2 minutes is enforced. As with join(), you must fork() or a preceeding Taskin a chain before you get() or the worker thread will erroneously assume this is fork()ed along a chain and may wait the full timeout. Task value is final and immutable after execution completes. You may safely use the Task as a value object. Since a Task is a "future" or a "promise" that will be executed as soon as processing and other associated resources become available, you may store the Task as a functional programming value object as soon as it is created. If you get() the value of the object before it has naturally executed, the get() will block and out-of-order execution will attempt to speed up execution. If you choose not to fork() the Task, this is a form of lazy execution at first use. Note that in this case references from the UI Thread will block until execution completes.
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException
        CancellationException
        TimeoutException

      • set

        public final java.lang.Object set(java.lang.Object value)
        Set the return value of this task during or at the end of execution. Note that although you can use this to set or override the initial input value of a task before fork()ing it, it is more clear and preferred to use the Task(Object) constructor to set the input value.
        Parameters:
        value -
        Returns:

      • fork

        public final Task fork()
        Execute this task asynchronously on a Worker thread. This will queue the Task with Worker.NORMAL_PRIORITY
        Returns:

      • join

                                   TimeoutException

        Returns:

      • join

        public final java.lang.Object join(long timeout)
                            throws java.lang.InterruptedException,
                                   CancellationException,
                                   TimeoutException
        Wait for a maximum of timeout milliseconds for the Task to run and return it's evaluation value, otherwise throw a TimeoutExeception. Similar to get(), except the total wait() time if the AsyncTask has not completed is explicitly limited to prevent long delays. Never call join() from the UI thread with a timeout greater than 100ms. This is still bad design and better handled with a chained Task or UITask. You will receive a debug warning, but are not prevented from making longer join() calls from the user interface Thread. If you call join() on chain()ed Task, note that there is by definition no out-of-order execution so you must wait for every previous step of the chain() to start and complete at their designated priorities. If you call join() a Task.SERIAL priority Task, note that there is by definition no out-of-order execution so you must wait for normal completion at the designated priority.
        Parameters:
        timeout - in milliseconds
        Returns:
        final evaluation result of the Task
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException - - task was running when it was explicitly canceled by another thread
        CancellationException - - task was explicitly canceled by another thread
        TimeoutException - - UITask failed to complete within timeout milliseconds

      • joinAll

        public static void joinAll(Task[] tasks)
                    throws java.lang.InterruptedException,
                           CancellationException,
                           TimeoutException
        Wait up to a Task.MAX_TIMEOUT milliseconds for all tasks in the list to complete execution. If any or all of them have any problem, the first associated Exception to occur will be thrown.
        Parameters:
        tasks -
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException
        CancellationException
        TimeoutException

      • joinAll

        public static void joinAll(Task[] tasks,
           long timeout)
                    throws java.lang.InterruptedException,
                           CancellationException,
                           TimeoutException
        Wait up to a maximum specified timeout for all tasks in the list to complete execution. If any or all of them have any problem, the first associated Exception to occur will be thrown.
        Parameters:
        tasks - - list of Tasks to wait for
        timeout - - milliseconds, max total time from for all Tasks to complete
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException
        CancellationException
        TimeoutException

      • chain

        public final Task chain(Task nextTask)
        Set a Task which will fork()ed after the current Task completes. nextTask == null is legal and has no effect. Each Task in a chain will run at the same priority as the previous Task in the chain unless you explicitly set a different priority for it.
        Parameters:
        nextTask -
        Returns:
        nextTask

      • getForkPriority

        public final int getForkPriority()
        Return the priority value applied when this Task was fork()ed. If the Task is not yet fork()ed, for example if it is part of a Task chain, this is the value which will be applied when it is forked.
        Returns:

      • cancel

        public boolean cancel(boolean mayInterruptIfRunning,
             java.lang.String reason)
        Cancel execution if possible. This is called on the Worker thread Do not override this unless you also call super.cancel(boolean). Override onCanceled() is the normal notification location, and is called from the UI thread with Task state updates handled for you.
        Parameters:
        mayInterruptIfRunning -
        reason -
        Returns:

      • onCanceled

        protected void onCanceled()
        This is executed on the UI thread Override if needed, the default implementation does nothing except provide debug output. Use getStatus() to distinguish between CANCELED and EXCEPTION states if necessary.

      • isCanceled

        public final boolean isCanceled()
        Check of the task has been had cancel() called or has thrown an uncaught exception while executing.
        Returns:

      • run

        public void run()
        The default implementation of run() does nothing. If you task.fork(Task.UI) then you should override this method. Your overriding run() method probably will want to access and display the result with getValue()
        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable
